elements.solution: Measure the time and effort reduction for second-listing creation when the duplicate-and-modify pattern is available versus requiring a fresh listing creation.

evidence.insight: Andreas describes both units as variations of each other: same building type, different floors. He naturally presents them together.
Requiring duplication of effort that produces no new information is a pure cost. The law of least effort predicts the host will postpone the second listing indefinitely.

elements.test_description: For multi-unit hosts (identified by having more than one listing), track: (1) time to create Listing 2 after publishing Listing 1, (2) number of fields modified in Listing 2 (versus fields carried forward from Listing 1), (3) second-listing creation rate (percentage of multi-unit hosts who create Listing 2 within 7 days of Listing 1), (4) time to complete Listing 2 versus time to complete Listing 1. Compare these metrics before and after implementing the duplicate-and-modify pattern.
elements.success_criteria: Listing 2 creation time is under 2 minutes (compared to under 5 minutes for Listing 1). At least 70% of multi-unit hosts create Listing 2 within 7 days of Listing 1. Number of fields modified in Listing 2 is under 30% of total fields (confirming 70%+ carry-forward). Second listing creation rate increases by at least 25% after implementing duplicate-and-modify.
elements.failure_meaning: If Listing 2 time is not significantly less than Listing 1, the carry-forward may not be working correctly (too many fields requiring modification, or the modification flow is as complex as the creation flow). If second-listing creation rate does not improve, the prompt to create a second listing may not be reaching hosts at the right moment, or multi-unit hosts may have reasons beyond effort to delay the second listing.
elements.implementation_hint: Tag listings with building_id to identify units in the same building. Track listing_created events with is_duplicate boolean and source_listing_id. Calculate field_modification_rate per listing. The prompt to add a second unit should appear immediately after the first listing is published, while the host is still engaged.

elements.title: Validate Cognitive Ease as the Foundation of Trust at First Touch
elements.problem: feels-001 asserts that the first 2 seconds of every phase transition must generate calm through cognitive ease. If the first sensory input is unfamiliar, System 1 flags the context as foreign and the host's trust from the call is not transferred.
elements.solution: Measure emotional first impressions using rapid-exposure testing and qualitative interviews to verify that the platform generates calm rather than confusion or anxiety.

evidence.insight: Andreas's calm, open tone indicates his System 1 had already approved Bryant. The platform must replicate this cognitive ease.

evidence.source: kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Lazy Controller and Illusions
evidence.insight: Cognitive ease produces the feeling of familiarity, which System 1 interprets as safety and truth.

elements.test_description: Post-call usability study with 6-8 hosts who have just completed a phone call with an agent. Within 1 hour of the call, send them the onboarding link and observe their first platform visit remotely (screen recording + audio). Capture: (1) first words spoken when the page loads (think-aloud), (2) time to first positive or negative verbalization, (3) body language if video is available (leaning in = engagement, leaning back = caution). After a 5-minute platform exploration, ask: 'How did the platform compare to your phone call with [agent name]?' (open-ended) and 'On a scale of 1-5, how calm or anxious did you feel when the page first loaded?'
elements.success_criteria: At least 5 of 8 hosts verbalize recognition or positive affect within 3 seconds of page load ('Oh, there is Bryant' or 'That is my address'). Calm rating averages 4+ on the 5-point scale. Qualitative comparison to the phone call clusters around 'felt like the same thing' rather than 'felt like a different experience.'
elements.failure_meaning: If hosts do not verbalize recognition quickly, the first-screen content is not anchored to their call experience. If calm ratings are low, the visual environment may be generating cognitive strain (too many elements, unfamiliar layout, corporate feel). If hosts describe the platform as a 'different experience' from the call, associative coherence is broken and the full trust bridge needs strengthening.
elements.implementation_hint: Coordinate with the sales team to schedule platform follow-ups within 1 hour of calls. Use remote usability testing tools (Lookback, UserTesting) that capture screen and audio. The timing is critical -- testing days after the call does not capture the warm priming state.

elements.title: Validate Relief of Guaranteed Income Through Tension-Relief Arc
elements.problem: feels-002 asserts that financial screens must follow a deliberate emotional sequence: show the total (tension: 'is this enough?'), then show the guarantee mechanism (relief: 'it is safe'). The 300ms delay between the number and the trust badges is critical for the tension-relief arc.
elements.solution: Test whether the tension-relief sequence (number first, then badges) produces higher reported confidence than simultaneous display or badge-first display.

evidence.insight: Andreas's emotional arc: analytical questioning about deposits and fees, then relief when Bryant explains credit checks and pre-authorization guarantee.
The payment guarantee works because it is a causal story. The narrative, not the claim, produces the emotion of relief.

elements.test_description: Show 8 hosts three versions of a proposal financial display: Version A (tension-relief): Monthly total appears first, then after a 300ms delay trust badges fade in below. Version B (simultaneous): Total and badges appear together. Version C (badge-first): Trust badges appear first, then the number. After each version, rate: 'How confident are you that you will receive this payment?' (1-5) and 'How did this screen make you feel?' (open-ended). Final forced-choice: 'Which version felt the most reassuring?'
elements.success_criteria: Version A (tension-relief) is selected as most reassuring by at least 5 of 8 hosts. Version A confidence rating averages at least 0.5 points higher than Version B or C. Open-ended responses for Version A include words like 'safe,' 'solid,' 'clear.' Version C (badge-first) shows lower confidence than Version A, confirming that claim-before-evidence triggers skepticism.
elements.failure_meaning: If simultaneous display (B) is preferred, the 300ms delay may feel unnecessary or patronizing. If badge-first (C) performs equally well, hosts may not be skeptical of claims the way the Kahneman framework predicts -- they may value reassurance regardless of order. If confidence ratings are low across all versions, the trust mechanism itself (credit verified, pre-authorized) may not be understood or believed.
elements.implementation_hint: Build three interactive mockups with identical data but different reveal timing. Use CSS animations with configurable delays. Test with hosts who have real financial stakes (property owners) rather than test participants without investment context.

elements.title: Validate Advisor Glow Creates Confidence and Commitment
elements.problem: feels-003 asserts that the advisor moment should produce the specific warmth of being consulted -- the 'glow' of expertise recognized. This emotional state creates commitment because the host has invested their knowledge.
elements.solution: Measure the emotional and behavioral impact of the advisor moment through qualitative sentiment analysis and downstream engagement metrics.

evidence.insight: Andreas's emotional peak: contributing practical recommendations. His tone is collaborative, not transactional. This is where evaluation becomes partnership.
Advising is flow-adjacent: concentrated but not controlled, drawing on System 1 pattern recognition. This is why advising is energizing while form-filling is depleting.

elements.test_description: During moderated usability tests, use a self-reported emotional probe at three points: (1) after completing Step 2 of the listing wizard (before the advisor prompt), (2) immediately after the advisor prompt response (if given), (3) after completing the full wizard. At each point, ask: 'Pick the word that best describes how you feel right now: tired, neutral, engaged, confident, accomplished.' Track whether the advisor prompt shifts the self-reported emotion in a positive direction. Also ask after the prompt: 'How did answering that question make you feel about your listing?' (open-ended).
elements.success_criteria: At least 4 of 6 hosts report a more positive emotion after the advisor prompt than before it (e.g., shift from 'neutral' or 'tired' to 'engaged' or 'confident'). Open-ended responses include language about ownership, expertise, or contribution ('my place,' 'I know this building,' 'glad they asked'). Hosts who engage with the advisor prompt are more likely to complete the remaining wizard steps than those who skip.
elements.failure_meaning: If no emotional shift is detected, the advisor prompt may not be distinctive enough from regular form fields -- the visual mode shift may not be working. If hosts report negative emotions after the prompt ('annoyed,' 'confused'), the question may be poorly phrased or the timing may be wrong (too early in the wizard, before the host feels established). If the prompt does not affect completion rates, the commitment mechanism may be weaker than the theory predicts for this audience.
elements.implementation_hint: Use in-session micro-surveys (a single emoji or word selector that appears inline, not as a pop-up) at each measurement point. Keep the interruption minimal to avoid the survey itself affecting the emotional state. Compare advisor-prompt engagers to skippers using propensity score matching.

elements.title: Validate Depletion-Aware Pacing with Decompression Moments
elements.problem: feels-004 asserts that the listing wizard must follow a pacing pattern that front-loads hard decisions, includes decompression moments, and frames remaining work as easy. Without this, the host experiences mounting pressure and declining decision quality.
elements.solution: Measure whether decompression moments (inserted after Steps 2-3 and 4-5) reduce the depletion curve observed in analytics.

evidence.source: kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Busy and Depleted System 2
evidence.insight: The parole judges' approval rate spikes after each meal and drops to near zero before the next. Decompression moments are the listing wizard's meal breaks.
Andreas arrives already busy and by call end is fatigued. The platform faces a depleted user from the start.

elements.test_description: A/B test the listing wizard with and without decompression moments. Variant A: after Step 2 and Step 4, a decompression screen appears showing progress summary ('Your unit details and pricing are set. The hard part is done.') with a 500ms pause before the next step reveals. Variant B: standard wizard with immediate transitions between all steps. Measure: (1) completion rate, (2) per-step time (to detect where depletion causes slowdown), (3) default acceptance rate per step (to detect where depletion causes mindless defaults), (4) post-completion satisfaction: 'How exhausting was this process?' (1-5, where 5 is not at all exhausting).
elements.success_criteria: Variant A completion rate is at least 10% higher than Variant B. Default acceptance rate in Steps 4-6 is no more than 15pp higher than Steps 1-3 in Variant A (compared to potentially 20pp+ in Variant B). Satisfaction rating averages 3.5+ for Variant A. The depletion curve (default acceptance by step) is measurably flatter in Variant A.
elements.failure_meaning: If decompression moments do not improve completion rate, they may be positioned at the wrong steps (the depletion peak may be at a different point than predicted). If satisfaction is not higher, the decompression moments may feel like delays rather than relief -- the copy may need to be more rewarding. If the depletion curve does not flatten, the hard decisions may not be sufficiently front-loaded in the step order.
elements.implementation_hint: Build the decompression screens as lightweight interstitials (not full pages) that appear inline between steps. The 500ms pause is a CSS animation delay, not a loading state. Track all per-step metrics with the variant as a dimension. Run for at least 3 weeks to reach statistical significance.

elements.title: Validate Associative Warmth: Emotional Rhyme Across Touchpoints
elements.problem: feels-005 asserts that every touchpoint must emotionally rhyme with the phone call's register: warm, professional, specific, personal. Emotional inconsistency between the call and the platform triggers System 1 suspicion.
elements.solution: Audit all platform copy (emails, notifications, error messages, empty states) for tonal consistency with the phone call's register, using a combination of manual review and user perception testing.

evidence.insight: The call's emotional fingerprint: warm, personal, competent, proactive. Every subsequent touchpoint is measured against this fingerprint.

evidence.source: kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Associative Machine and The Marvels of Priming
evidence.insight: Emotional associations transfer from one context to another. Incoherence triggers System 1 alarm.

elements.test_description: Conduct a comprehensive copy audit of all host-facing text across the platform, organized by touchpoint: (1) onboarding emails, (2) dashboard welcome message, (3) wizard step instructions, (4) error messages, (5) empty states, (6) notification text, (7) proposal display text, (8) active lease dashboard text. For each touchpoint, evaluate against the call register criteria: does it sound like something Bryant would say? Is it warm without being casual? Is it specific without being overwhelming? Is it personal without being intimate? Score each touchpoint 1-5 on register match. Then test with 4-6 hosts: show them the phone call transcript and then the platform copy, and ask 'Does this feel like the same person or company?' (1-5 scale).
elements.success_criteria: All touchpoints score 3.5+ on register match in the internal audit. At least 4 of 6 hosts rate the platform experience as 'the same person or company' at 4+ on the 5-point scale. No individual touchpoint scores below 3 (any score below 3 indicates a tonal break that needs immediate correction). Error messages and empty states -- traditionally the most corporate-sounding copy -- score at least 3.5.
elements.failure_meaning: If register match is low for specific touchpoints, those touchpoints are using corporate, technical, or impersonal language that breaks the warm chain. The fix is copy rewriting, not design change. If hosts perceive the platform as a different entity from the call, the emotional warmth is not carrying through the digital transition -- the copy, the visual warmth, and the agent presence may all need strengthening in concert.
elements.implementation_hint: Create a copy audit spreadsheet with columns for: touchpoint location, current copy text, register match score (1-5), recommended revision (if score below 4), and the 'Bryant test' (would Bryant say this? Yes/No). Schedule quarterly copy audits as new features are added.

elements.title: Validate Forward Momentum at Every Interaction Close
elements.problem: feels-006 asserts that every interaction conclusion must include a confirmation of what was accomplished AND a preview of what comes next. Dead-end completion screens ('Done.') dissipate forward momentum.
elements.solution: Measure whether next-step previews at completion points increase same-session continuation to the next phase.

evidence.insight: The call ends with 3 clear forward-looking elements: open channel, enthusiasm for the next step, promise of continuation.
When the host sees a preview of the next step, System 1 begins preparing for it, reducing cognitive startup cost.

elements.test_description: A/B test completion screens at two key points: (1) after listing publication and (2) after proposal acceptance. Variant A (forward momentum): completion confirmation + specific next-step preview ('Your listing is live. Bryant will share it with matched tenants this week. You will get a notification when someone sends a proposal.'). Variant B (dead end): completion confirmation only ('Your listing has been published.' with 'View Listing' and 'Return to Dashboard' buttons). Measure: (1) same-session continuation rate (does the host do anything else before leaving?), (2) time-to-return for the next action (how long before the host comes back?), (3) next-phase engagement (does the host respond to the first proposal faster if they were in the forward-momentum group?).
elements.success_criteria: Variant A shows at least 20% higher same-session continuation rate. Time-to-return for the next action is at least 25% shorter for Variant A. Qualitative: hosts in Variant A describe the completion as 'I know what happens next' rather than 'I guess I am done now.'
elements.failure_meaning: If forward momentum copy does not increase continuation, the host may be genuinely done for the session (depleted after the wizard) and no copy can overcome that. In this case, the forward momentum is better invested in the re-engagement notification (behaves-006) rather than the completion screen. If time-to-return is similar, the preview may not be creating urgency or curiosity -- the next step may not be interesting enough to pull the host back.
elements.implementation_hint: Use feature flags for the completion screen variants. Track session_continued (any action after completion screen view within the same session) and next_action_timestamp (first action in the next session). The forward-momentum copy should reference the specific next step with a time estimate.

elements.title: Validate Depleted User Dignity: Invisible Smart Defaults
elements.problem: feels-007 asserts that smart defaults must be invisible accommodations, not labeled recommendations. The host should feel they are confirming research-based suggestions, not outsourcing their judgment. Highlighting that defaults are pre-filled diminishes the host's sense of agency.
elements.solution: Test whether different framings of default values affect the host's perceived ownership of their listing.

evidence.source: kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Busy and Depleted System 2
evidence.insight: Depleted hosts CAN make good decisions but will not unless the cost is very low. Smart defaults make the cost near-zero while preserving dignity.
Andreas processes at full capacity early in the call but has less energy by the end. The platform must handle this transition gracefully.

elements.test_description: Show 6 hosts two versions of the pricing step (Step 4) with identical default values. Version A (invisible dignity): Fields pre-populated with 'Average for Washington Heights walk-ups: $2,400/mo' as the source label, no mention of 'recommended' or 'pre-filled.' Version B (highlighted recommendation): Banner at top: 'We have pre-filled your pricing based on similar listings. Review our suggestions below.' After completing each version, ask: 'Who decided the pricing for your listing -- you or the platform?' (open-ended) and 'How much ownership do you feel over your listing?' (1-5 scale).
elements.success_criteria: In Version A, at least 4 of 6 hosts describe the pricing decision as their own ('I decided' or 'I confirmed'). In Version B, at least 3 of 6 attribute the decision to the platform ('they suggested' or 'it was pre-filled'). Ownership rating for Version A is at least 0.7 points higher than Version B on the 5-point scale.
elements.failure_meaning: If both versions produce similar ownership feelings, the framing difference may be too subtle to affect perception -- hosts may not care whether defaults are labeled as recommendations or data. If Version B produces higher ownership (because it makes the defaults visible for review), transparency may be more important than invisibility for this audience.
elements.implementation_hint: Build two interactive prototypes of Step 4 with identical default values and identical modification affordances. The only difference is the framing copy and the presence/absence of the 'pre-filled' banner. Test with hosts who have real pricing context (actual property owners) to ensure the default values feel realistic.

elements.title: Validate Human Thread: Agent Accessibility as Psychological Safety Net
elements.problem: feels-008 asserts that the host must always feel one step from a real person. The 'Message Bryant' action must be within 2 taps from any screen. The agent's presence is a safety net -- most hosts will not use it, but knowing it is there reduces anxiety.
elements.solution: Test whether the persistent visibility of the agent contact action reduces confusion-related abandonment and support tickets.

evidence.insight: Andreas establishes a permanent human channel: 'You can just email me at any time.' The platform must never replace this expectation.
The feeling of connection to Bryant is genuine. The platform risks creating a cognitive illusion by showing the photo without real accessibility.

elements.test_description: Track: (1) visibility of the 'Message [agent name]' action (is it accessible within 2 taps from every authenticated screen?), (2) usage rate (what percentage of hosts use the agent messaging action?), (3) correlation between agent-message visibility and confusion-related abandonment (do hosts who encounter the agent contact at a confusion point continue versus hosts who encounter a FAQ or help center?), (4) support ticket analysis: are tickets phrased as 'I could not reach my agent' or 'the system did not work'? The first indicates the human thread is valued but broken; the second indicates it was never relied upon.
elements.success_criteria: Agent contact action is accessible in 2 or fewer taps from 100% of authenticated screens (automated accessibility audit). Usage rate is between 5-15% (low usage indicates the safety net is working -- hosts feel safe without needing to actually use it). Confusion-related abandonment is at least 20% lower on screens where the agent contact is visible versus screens where it is not. Support tickets mentioning the agent by name indicate relationship (positive), not frustration (negative).
elements.failure_meaning: If usage rate exceeds 20%, the platform itself may be too confusing, forcing hosts to rely on human support. This is a platform design problem, not a safety net success. If usage rate is 0%, the agent contact may be too hidden or hosts may not realize it connects to a real person. If abandonment is not affected by agent visibility, the human thread may not be the safety mechanism for this audience -- they may prefer self-service help content.
elements.implementation_hint: Run an automated audit of all authenticated pages to verify the 2-tap agent-access constraint. Track agent_message_opened events with the originating page as context. Create a dashboard showing usage rate by page to identify screens where hosts most need the human safety net.

elements.title: Journey-Level Validation: End-to-End Conversion from Call to Published Listing
elements.problem: Individual element validations test specific design decisions, but the host journey is a connected sequence where each phase's success depends on the prior phase. The end-to-end conversion from completed phone call to published listing is the ultimate test of whether the design stack's principles work together: System 1 trust gates pass, depletion is managed, speed matches the call, trust transfers from human to digital, and the host completes the full wizard.
elements.solution: Track the end-to-end funnel from phone call completion to published listing as the primary success metric for the entire design stack.

evidence.insight: 8 reinforcement clusters show that multiple layers converge on the same principles. The end-to-end funnel tests whether these converging principles actually produce the intended outcome: a host who went from call to published listing without dropping off.

System 1 trust gating, progressive depletion, priming transfer, and the human-to-digital handoff are all cross-phase patterns that can only be validated by measuring the entire journey, not individual phases.

elements.test_description: Build a cohort-based funnel analysis tracking every host from phone call completion through published listing. Funnel stages: (1) phone call completed, (2) onboarding email sent, (3) onboarding email opened, (4) first platform visit, (5) listing wizard started, (6) listing wizard Step 3 reached (past the typical depletion dropout point), (7) listing published. Track conversion rate at each stage, time between stages, and the total time from call to published listing. Segment by agent, property type, and number of units. Run weekly cohort reports to track improvement as design elements are implemented.
elements.success_criteria: End-to-end conversion rate (call completed to listing published) above 40%. Time from call to published listing under 48 hours for 60% of converting hosts. No single funnel stage shows a conversion rate below 60% (no stage is a black hole). The highest dropout stage should be identifiable and addressable.
elements.failure_meaning: If end-to-end conversion is below 40%, identify which stage is the primary bottleneck. If Stage 3 (email opened) to Stage 4 (first platform visit) is the weakest link, the trust bridge (works-004, communicates-006) is failing. If Stage 5 (wizard started) to Stage 6 (Step 3 reached) is weakest, depletion design (works-002, feels-004) is failing. If Stage 6 to Stage 7 (published) is weakest, the later wizard steps need simplification. The funnel diagnosis points directly to which design element cluster needs attention.
elements.implementation_hint: Integrate CRM data (phone call events) with platform analytics (user actions) using a shared host identifier. Build the funnel in the analytics platform with stage timestamps. Create a weekly dashboard showing the funnel with conversion rates, median time between stages, and week-over-week trends. Flag any stage where conversion drops below 50% for immediate investigation.

elements.title: Journey-Level Validation: Emotional Arc Consistency from Discovery to Active Lease
elements.problem: Layer 5 defines a progressive emotional arc: calm (discovery) -> relief (evaluation/pricing) -> confidence (listing creation) -> momentum (wizard) -> safety (active lease). If any phase breaks the emotional progression -- a warm call followed by a cold platform, or a confident listing creation followed by an anxious proposal experience -- the associative coherence is disrupted and the host's cumulative trust erodes.
elements.solution: Conduct longitudinal sentiment tracking across the full host journey, measuring whether the emotional arc progresses as designed or breaks at specific transitions.

evidence.insight: The designed arc is: calm -> relief -> confidence -> momentum -> safety -> curiosity. Each phase builds on the emotional foundation of the prior phase.
The coherence auditor confirms the arc is progressive and conflict-free. No phase targets an emotion that contradicts a prior phase.

elements.test_description: Longitudinal qualitative study with 4-6 hosts tracked from phone call through first proposal acceptance (approximately 2-4 weeks). At each phase transition, conduct a brief check-in (5 minutes, via the host's preferred channel -- likely text or email): 'One word: how are you feeling about the process right now?' and 'Is there anything about the experience that surprised you -- positively or negatively?' Compile the single-word emotional descriptors across phases for each host and map them against the designed arc. At the final check-in (after proposal acceptance), conduct a 15-minute retrospective interview: 'Walk me through the journey from your phone call to now. Where did things feel smooth? Where did things feel off?'
elements.success_criteria: At least 3 of 5 hosts show an emotional trajectory that matches the designed arc (calm -> positive growth, not calm -> frustration). No host reports an emotional regression (e.g., confident at listing creation but anxious at proposal review) at any transition. Retrospective interviews identify no more than 1 significant emotional break point per host. The most common single-word descriptors across all hosts are neutral-to-positive ('easy,' 'fine,' 'good,' 'smooth') rather than negative ('confusing,' 'frustrating,' 'slow').
elements.failure_meaning: If hosts report emotional regression at a specific transition, that transition is the weakest link in the emotional arc and the design elements governing it need revision. If multiple hosts identify the same break point, the problem is systematic (a design flaw) rather than individual (a host-specific circumstance). If the most common descriptors are negative, the overall experience is failing regardless of individual element quality -- the gestalt is broken even if parts work.
elements.implementation_hint: Recruit hosts at the phone call stage (coordinate with the sales team). Schedule check-ins at natural phase boundaries: immediately after the call, after first platform visit, after listing publication, after first proposal notification, after proposal action. Use text-based check-ins to minimize effort. Record the retrospective interview for qualitative analysis. This is a high-touch study that should run quarterly with small cohorts.

elements.title: Design the Stays Manager as a System 1 Weekly Dashboard, Not a System 2 Management Console
elements.problem: The Guest Leases page / Stays Manager is the most frequently visited part of the platform for active guests. A guest with a 13-week lease visits this page at least 13 times -- likely more, since they also check payment status, review completed stays, upload photos, and manage date changes. The current Stays Manager design (as described in the guest journey document) presents a data table with columns for Week #, Period, Status, and Actions. This is a System 2 interface: it requires the guest to scan rows, identify the current week, determine its status, and select the appropriate action. Each weekly visit forces the guest to re-orient in a table of 13+ rows. Kahneman's research on cognitive ease shows that 'as you become skilled in a task, its demand for energy diminishes.' But a table that grows with each passing week does not become easier -- it becomes harder, because the completed weeks accumulate visual noise that the guest must filter past to find the current week. The weekly visit should be a System 1 glance ('everything is fine, nothing needs my attention') not a System 2 scan ('let me find my current week in this table and figure out what to do').
elements.solution: Restructure the Stays Manager around the current week as the primary focal point, with completed weeks collapsed and future weeks summarized. On each visit, the guest should see: (1) A hero card for the current or next upcoming stay: 'Week 7: Oct 14-18. Status: In Progress. [No action needed]' or 'Week 6: Oct 7-11. Status: Completed. [Leave Review] [Upload Photos].' (2) A collapsed summary of past weeks: '6 stays completed. All reviewed.' Expandable on demand. (3) A compact preview of upcoming weeks: '6 weeks remaining. Next: Week 8, Oct 21-25.' (4) A notification-style alert area for any pending date changes, payment issues, or host messages. The page loads with the answer to the guest's primary question: 'What do I need to do right now?' This is a System 1 assessment (glance at a single card) rather than a System 2 scan (parse a 13-row table). The full table remains accessible for guests who want the detailed view, but it is not the default.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 392-408 (Stays Management)
evidence.quote: Stays (X) - Individual visit tracking. Stays Table: Columns: Week #, Period (date range), Status (Not Started, In Progress, Completed), Actions. Available Actions: Review, Upload Photos, Report Issue, No action available.
evidence.insight: The current design presents all stays as equal rows in a table. Week 1 (completed two months ago) and Week 13 (three weeks from now) have the same visual weight. The guest must visually scan to find the relevant row, which is a System 2 task that should not be required on a page visited weekly.

evidence.quote: Monday to Friday is a very popular usage pattern... typically looking for really weeknights or weekdays each week... 2-3 month commitments typical.
evidence.insight: The primary guest persona is a hybrid worker visiting 4-5 nights per week for 2-3 months. This means 8-13 weekly stays. The Stays Manager must handle this volume without creating a wall of data. A hybrid worker checking their Stays Manager on Monday morning before heading to the property should get their answer in under 3 seconds.

evidence.quote: As you become skilled in a task, its demand for energy diminishes... A general 'law of least effort' applies to cognitive as well as physical exertion.
evidence.insight: Weekly visits should become easier over time, not harder. A table with more completed rows each week becomes harder to scan. A hero card showing only the current week becomes a familiar pattern that the guest processes with decreasing effort on each visit -- exactly the skill acquisition curve Kahneman describes.

evidence.quote: System 2 also has a natural speed... there is little strain... Just like a stroll. Accelerating beyond my strolling speed completely changes the experience.
evidence.insight: The weekly Stays Manager check-in should be a cognitive 'stroll': glance at one card, confirm status, leave. It should never require the cognitive acceleration of parsing a multi-row table. The System 2 'sprint' should be reserved for actual management tasks (date changes, reviews), not for basic orientation.

elements.user_goal: On each weekly visit to the Stays Manager, immediately see what needs my attention right now without scanning a table or searching for my current week.
elements.company_goal: Increase weekly return rate to the Stays Manager by making the experience effortless, and increase completion rate for per-stay actions (reviews, photo uploads) by surfacing them at the right moment rather than burying them in table rows.
elements.time_budget: Under 3 seconds to answer 'what do I need to do this week?' on each visit. The hero card must be visible without scrolling. The full table is available but never the default view.
anti_goals: DO NOT present all stays as equal-weight rows in a flat table as the default view. Completed stays, current stay, and future stays have different information needs and different urgency levels.
DO NOT force the guest to scroll past completed weeks to find the current one. The current week is always the primary element.
DO NOT show 'No action available' for future stays in the default view. This is noise. Future stays should be summarized ('6 weeks remaining') not individually listed.
DO NOT remove the table view entirely. Some guests will want the full spreadsheet. Provide it as a secondary view, not the primary one.
elements.success_metric: Average time-to-first-action on the Stays Manager page (time from page load to the guest clicking an action or leaving). Target: under 8 seconds for routine weekly visits. Secondary: per-stay review completion rate above 60% (currently unmeasured).

coherence_note.similarity: Both address ego depletion across multi-step processes. The existing library element (Design for the Depleted User) prescribes smart defaults, save-and-resume, and decompression moments for the host journey. The new guest-run element (Stays Manager as System 1 Dashboard) prescribes restructuring the most-visited page to minimize cognitive load on depleted hybrid workers who visit weekly.

elements.title: Eliminate Off-Platform Communication as the Default Coordination Channel
elements.problem: Brad communicates with host Nneka via text messages for all schedule changes (01:23-01:42). Bryant acknowledges the need for in-app messaging (09:07-09:21: 'have the ability to message with Brad... having some way to talk with Brad would be useful'). When the host-guest relationship operates through text messages, the platform becomes invisible during the most active phase of the journey. This creates three compounding failures: (a) No enforcement of pricing rules -- Nneka is absorbing rescheduling costs at old rates because there is no system to calculate and present the fair price adjustment. (b) No record of agreements -- if Brad and Nneka disagree about what was agreed via text, neither party has platform-backed evidence. (c) No data for Split Lease -- the platform cannot learn from, optimize, or even observe the most critical interactions in the guest journey. Kahneman's priming research predicts that once the guest is primed to use text messages for coordination ('this is how I talk to my host'), they will continue using text messages even after an in-app tool exists. The platform must intervene in the workflow, not just offer an alternative channel.
elements.solution: Make the platform the path of least resistance for every host-guest interaction during active_lease: (1) When a guest needs to change dates, the platform flow must be faster than composing a text message. Pre-filled dates, one-tap change types, and instant availability visibility make the platform the easier path. (2) When the host responds to a change request, the guest receives a push notification with the decision, not a text message. The notification links directly to the updated Stays Manager. (3) For unstructured communication (questions about the space, logistics), provide a simple messaging interface within the Guest Leases page. Keep it adjacent to the stays and date change sections so context is always visible. (4) For the transition period: when a guest or host initiates contact off-platform (detected by the absence of in-platform activity paired with a schedule change), the platform should prompt: 'It looks like your stay dates changed. Want to log this change so your payment schedule stays accurate?' This bridges off-platform behavior back to the platform without punishing the user.

evidence.quote: He was texting me and saying, Hey, you know, I can't make it for another day... if I have availability.
evidence.insight: Text messaging is the current default for schedule coordination. This is not a technology failure but an experience failure: the platform offers no tool that is easier than texting. Until the platform tool is faster and simpler, texting will remain the default.

evidence.quote: Also have the ability to message with Brad. I know you have his number as well, but having some way to talk with Brad would be useful.
evidence.insight: Even the host recognizes the need for in-platform communication. The absence of messaging is not just a guest problem; it creates friction for both parties and forces both into informal channels.

evidence.quote: Exposure to a word causes immediate and measurable changes in the ease with which many related words can be evoked... The 'Florida effect' involves two stages of priming. First, the set of words primes thoughts of old age; second, these thoughts prime a behavior.
evidence.insight: Once a guest is primed to use text messages for host communication, this primes the behavior of reaching for their phone's messaging app every time they need to contact the host. Breaking this priming requires the platform to insert itself into the behavioral chain before the guest reaches for the text app -- ideally through a push notification or a visible 'Request Change' button on the Stays Manager page they already visit.

evidence.quote: It's not working financially... the new dates are priced higher now.
evidence.insight: Off-platform communication fails to enforce pricing rules. Nneka absorbed pricing losses because there was no system to calculate and present seasonal rate adjustments during a text-message rescheduling conversation. The platform must own the pricing calculation, which means it must own the communication channel.

elements.user_goal: Handle all schedule changes and host communication through one place that keeps a record, shows me availability, and tells me what things cost -- without needing my host's phone number.
elements.company_goal: Capture all host-guest interactions inside the platform to enforce pricing rules, maintain a dispute-resolution record, and generate behavioral data that improves matching and retention.
elements.time_budget: Any in-platform action must be completable in less time than composing an equivalent text message. For a date change: under 45 seconds (vs. ~30 seconds for a text, plus wait time for a response). For a simple message: under 15 seconds (matching text speed).
anti_goals: DO NOT block or prevent off-platform communication. Guests and hosts will always have each other's contact info. The goal is to make the platform the better option, not the only option.
DO NOT create a messaging system that is slower or more cumbersome than texting. If the in-app messaging requires more taps than opening a text conversation, it will not be used.
DO NOT treat messaging as a separate feature from stays management. Messages should be contextual: attached to specific stays, date changes, or issues, not a standalone inbox.
DO NOT send notifications for every message. Notify for actionable items (change request, payment issue) and batch non-urgent updates.
elements.success_metric: In-platform communication rate: percentage of schedule changes and host-guest messages that originate inside the platform. Target: above 70% within 6 months of messaging launch. Leading indicator: percentage of date changes that are platform-initiated vs. manually entered by the Split Lease team.

coherence_note.similarity: Both address the gap between conversational interaction speed and platform interaction speed. The existing library element prescribes matching the platform's cognitive speed to the phone call. The new element prescribes eliminating off-platform communication by making the platform faster than texting for date changes.

elements.title: Proposal Pipeline as Anxiety-Resolving Status Stream
elements.problem: After submitting a proposal, the guest enters a waiting state with no visibility into whether the host has seen it, is reviewing it, or has forgotten about it. Kahneman's research on System 2 activation during uncertainty predicts continuous cognitive drain: the guest cannot stop monitoring the uncertain outcome, which depletes the same System 2 resources needed for their job. Brad's behavior confirms this pattern -- he resorts to texting Nneka directly because the platform provides no status channel. The proposal pipeline currently shows stage names and completion status but not who acts next or how long to wait. This opacity during the most anxiety-producing part of the journey forces the guest into off-platform behavior (texting, emailing the agent) that fragments the experience and removes the platform from the relationship.
elements.solution: Transform every waiting state in the proposal pipeline into an active status display that resolves uncertainty. At each stage, the pipeline shows three pieces of information: (1) Current status: who must act ('Waiting on host,' 'Your action needed,' 'Split Lease processing'). (2) Time context: elapsed time since last action and expected resolution ('Submitted 14h ago. Hosts typically respond within 48h.'). (3) Next action preview: what will happen when the waiting ends ('When your host responds, you will see their terms here and can accept, counter, or decline.'). The interaction pattern for status updates uses progressive disclosure within the pipeline itself: the current stage expands into a card showing full context, while completed stages collapse to checkmarks and upcoming stages collapse to dots. When a stage transitions (host responds, document is ready), the guest receives a push notification and the pipeline animates the stage change on next visit -- the completed stage slides into its checkmark position and the new current stage expands into the card. This animation takes 300ms and uses the out easing, providing a sense of progress without demanding attention.

evidence.quote: He was texting me and saying, Hey, you know, I can't make it for another day... if I have availability.
evidence.insight: Brad texts because the platform provides no status feedback. The texting is not a preference; it is a workaround for opacity. If the platform had shown 'Your request was sent to Nneka 2 hours ago -- she typically responds within 24 hours,' Brad would have no reason to text.

evidence.quote: System 2 is activated when an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains.
evidence.insight: The guest's model after submitting a proposal is: 'I acted, something should happen.' When the pipeline shows no change, the model is violated, and System 2 activates to manage the ambiguity. This activation persists as background cognitive drain until resolved. Status updates resolve the model: 'Nothing has happened yet, and that is normal.'

evidence.quote: We'll be working on basically just having a way to notify you. So you'll know when a request comes in and then from there you'd be able to either accept the request.
evidence.insight: Bryant describes a notification system that does not yet exist. The proposal pipeline must be built with notifications as a core interaction channel, not an afterthought. Every status change generates a push notification that links directly to the relevant pipeline stage.

evidence.source: kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Busy and Depleted System 2
evidence.quote: Activities that impose high demands on System 2 require self-control, and the exertion of self-control is depleting and unpleasant.
evidence.insight: Monitoring an uncertain proposal outcome is a continuous, low-grade System 2 demand that drains the guest's cognitive budget for their work. Each status update that resolves uncertainty releases System 2 resources. The pipeline is not just a UI component -- it is a depletion prevention mechanism.

states.default: Pipeline visible with current stage expanded into a card showing status, action assignment, and time context. Completed stages show checkmarks. Upcoming stages show dots with names in muted text. The 'who acts next' tag is the most prominent element on the current stage card.
states.loading: Pipeline skeleton renders instantly with correct stage count and position markers. The current stage card skeleton is taller than completed/upcoming indicators, maintaining the visual hierarchy even before data loads. Data populates the current stage card within 300ms.
states.empty: Before any proposal is submitted (guest is configuring), the pipeline shows all stages as upcoming with a 'preview' label: 'After you submit, your proposal will go through these stages.' This sets expectations before commitment and reduces post-submission anxiety by making the process familiar.
states.error: If pipeline status fails to load, the current stage area shows the last known state with a timestamp: 'Status as of [time]. Could not check for updates. [Retry].' The guest is never left with no information -- stale information with a timestamp is better than a blank error state.
states.success: When a stage completes, the current stage card plays a brief completion animation: the card content fades, a checkmark scales up from center (200ms, spring easing), and the card shrinks into the checkmark position on the timeline (300ms, out easing). Simultaneously, the next stage expands from its dot into the new current stage card. The overall effect is a conveyor belt of progress.

elements.transition_principle: Stage transitions are the most important animations in the entire guest journey because they represent progress toward having a place to stay. They must feel substantial enough to register as meaningful progress but not so elaborate that they slow the guest's ability to read the new state. The completion-to-expansion transition uses a staggered timing: the outgoing stage completes its collapse (200ms) before the incoming stage begins its expansion (200ms), creating a clear sequential narrative rather than a chaotic simultaneous change.

timing.response_target: 300ms for pipeline data load, 200ms for stage collapse animation, 200ms for stage expand animation (staggered after collapse), push notification delivered within 60 seconds of status change
timing.easing: cubic-bezier(0.34, 1.56, 0.64, 1) for checkmark scale-up (spring, celebratory), cubic-bezier(0.16, 1, 0.3, 1) for card collapse/expand (out, smooth)
timing.rationale: The spring easing for the checkmark conveys a small celebration -- the stage is done, progress was made. The out easing for the structural card transitions keeps the layout change smooth and predictable. The 400ms total transition time (200ms collapse + 200ms expand) is fast enough to feel responsive but slow enough for the guest to register that something changed.

elements.journey_state_awareness: First-time proposal submitter: the pipeline includes brief explanatory text at each stage ('Your host will review your dates, rate, and duration. They can accept, counter, or decline.'). Returning user (has completed a proposal before): explanatory text is removed; the pipeline shows only status, assignment, and timing. During negotiation (host countered): the current stage card expands to show the counter-offer terms inline -- the guest never navigates to a separate page to see what changed. At acceptance: the pipeline collapses entirely and is replaced by a confirmation card with move-in details.
edge_cases: Host has not responded in 72+ hours: the pipeline shows an escalation option ('Your host has not responded. [Send a reminder] or [Contact Split Lease support]') without making the guest feel like the proposal failed.

Guest submits a proposal and immediately wants to modify it: a 'Modify proposal' option is available for 30 minutes after submission (before the host sees it). After 30 minutes, the guest must wait for the host's response and then counter.

Multiple proposals to different hosts: each proposal has its own pipeline, accessible through tabs or a list view. The most recent/active proposal is the default view. No merged or combined pipeline that confuses different hosts' responses.

The host accepts instantly (within seconds of submission): the pipeline skips the waiting state entirely and animates directly from submission to acceptance, with a slightly longer celebration animation (500ms) to mark the significance of securing housing.

coherence_note.similarity: Both address notifications as continuation mechanisms rather than interruptions. The existing library element prescribes notification-as-continuation for the host journey (notifications feel like the next thing Bryant would say). The new guest-run element prescribes the proposal pipeline as an anxiety-resolving status stream with push notifications that resolve uncertainty.

elements.title: Self-Service Date Changes at Conversational Speed
elements.problem: The guest's most frequent interaction with Split Lease during an active lease is managing schedule changes: replacing a night they cannot make, adding an extra night, or swapping dates. Currently, no self-service rescheduling tool exists (Bryant confirms at 00:32-01:02 that 'we've been working on this rescheduling tool'). Brad must text Nneka directly ('He was texting me and saying, Hey, you know, I can't make it for another day,' 01:23-01:42), Nneka must manually check her Airbnb calendar, and the Split Lease team mediates. This three-party process for a single date change forces the guest to context-switch from their work responsibilities (hybrid workers are the primary guest persona, per Bryant at 10:17-12:17) into a manual coordination task. Kahneman's law of least effort predicts that guests facing this friction will either stop rescheduling (leading to no-shows and wasted nights) or handle everything off-platform (text messages), where the platform loses visibility, cannot enforce pricing rules, and cannot protect either party. The Stays Manager UI (Guest Leases page) shows per-week stays with status badges and a Date Change section with Accept/Reject actions, but without a self-service initiation flow, the guest has no way to start a change request from inside the platform.
elements.solution: Build the date change flow as a three-tap interaction that completes within the guest's existing Stays Manager visit: (1) Tap the specific week/stay row to open it. (2) Select the change type (replace night, add night, remove night) from clearly labeled options that show the pricing implication inline ('Replace: same rate,' 'Add: current market rate,' 'Remove: refund amount'). (3) See available alternative dates (pulled from synced host availability), pick one, and submit. The host receives a notification and accepts or counters. The entire guest-side flow should take under 60 seconds. The key design principle: the Date Change section in the Stays Manager must be the entry point, not a separate page or a message thread. The guest is already visiting this page weekly to check their stays. Meet them where they already are, at the cognitive speed of their existing visit pattern.

evidence.quote: He was texting me and saying, Hey, you know, I can't make it for another day... if I have availability.
evidence.insight: Brad's rescheduling process is entirely manual and off-platform. The guest's need is simple ('I can't make Thursday, can I do Tuesday instead?') but the process requires texting the host, waiting for a response, and hoping the dates align. Each step introduces delay and failure risk.

evidence.quote: We've been working on this rescheduling tool and specifically working more on the traveler side... looking to improve that.
evidence.insight: Bryant confirms that no self-service rescheduling tool exists yet. The fact that the platform team is actively building this tool confirms the gap is known and critical.

evidence.quote: A general 'law of least effort' applies to cognitive as well as physical exertion. The law asserts that if there are several ways of achieving the same goal, people will eventually gravitate to the least demanding course of action.
evidence.insight: The least demanding course of action for a date change is texting the host. If the platform tool is not faster and easier than a text message, the guest will never use it. The platform must compete with the cognitive simplicity of 'Hey, can I switch Thursday for Tuesday?'

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 409-438 (Date Change Section)
evidence.quote: Request Changes button - Initiate modification. Change Types: Add nights, Remove nights, Swap dates. Pricing: Buying back nights: Host pays guest. Adding nights: Guest pays host. Fair market rate calculation.
evidence.insight: The UI structure exists in the design but the guest-initiated flow is missing. The Date Change section shows incoming requests and their statuses but does not provide a clear, fast path for the guest to create a new request from a specific stay week.

elements.user_goal: Change a date on my active lease in under 60 seconds, from inside the page I already visit weekly, without leaving the platform or texting anyone.
elements.company_goal: Capture 100% of schedule changes inside the platform where pricing rules are enforced, availability is verified in real time, and both parties have a record of what was agreed.
elements.time_budget: Under 60 seconds for the guest to initiate a date change request. Under 30 seconds for a simple replace (same night type, same week). The benchmark is: faster than composing and sending a text message.
anti_goals: DO NOT require the guest to navigate away from the Stays Manager to initiate a date change. The change flow must live inside the page they already visit.
DO NOT present date change as a messaging thread. It is a structured action with specific inputs (old date, new date, change type), not a conversation.
DO NOT hide pricing implications until after the guest submits. The cost difference must be visible before the guest commits to the change.
DO NOT require the guest to understand the difference between 'replace,' 'add,' and 'swap' through labels alone. Show the financial consequence of each option inline.
DO NOT force the guest to check host availability manually or guess which dates are open. Show only available dates.
elements.success_metric: Percentage of date changes initiated through the platform (vs. off-platform text/call). Target: above 80% within 3 months of tool launch. Secondary: median time from change initiation to submission under 45 seconds.

coherence_note.similarity: Both address the System 1 trust gate at transitions and critical moments. The existing library element prescribes passing System 1's automatic assessment at every phase transition (visual consistency, familiar language, explicit connection to prior phase). The new guest-run element prescribes self-service date changes at conversational speed within the Stays Manager -- which is itself a System 1 design principle (meet the guest where they already are, in the page they already visit).

elements.title: The Price Surprise Shield: Preventing Betrayal Before It Forms
elements.problem: Nneka states that rescheduling at the original rate is 'not working financially' because seasonal pricing has increased from $1,170-$1,175 to a higher rate. Brad anchored on the original price -- it was the first financial number he evaluated, and Kahneman's anchoring research shows that first numbers become the reference point against which all subsequent numbers are judged. When Brad encounters a higher rate during rescheduling, the emotional experience is not 'the market price changed' but 'I was promised one price and now they want more.' This is the betrayal emotion -- the most destructive feeling in a platform relationship. Betrayal is not caused by the price increase itself; it is caused by the gap between what the guest expected and what they encountered. The platform currently makes no effort to close this gap before it opens. The listing page shows one nightly rate. The proposal confirms one total. The rescheduling section uses abstract labels ('fair market rate calculation') instead of concrete numbers. At every stage, the emotional setup is 'your price is fixed' and the emotional payoff is 'your price changed.' This sequence manufactures betrayal.
elements.solution: Prevent the betrayal emotion by eliminating the expectation gap before commitment. At listing evaluation, when dates span pricing seasons, show the rate range ('$280-$301/night depending on season') so the guest's anchor is a range, not a single number. At proposal confirmation, include a one-line seasonal note ('Date changes are priced at the rate for the new dates'). At every date change in the Stays Manager, show the original rate next to the new rate with the delta. The emotional principle is: prepare the guest for variability before they experience it. A guest who was told 'rates vary by season' and then sees a seasonal adjustment feels informed. A guest who was shown one rate and then sees a different rate feels deceived. The emotional architecture is identical to Kahneman's Muller-Lyer illusion: you cannot change the feeling (the higher rate will always feel worse than the original), but you can prevent the surprise that amplifies the feeling into betrayal.

evidence.quote: It's not working financially... Originally when I... I believe $1,170, $1,175. And that was... therefore I am not able to do that.
evidence.insight: The host cannot honor the original rate for rescheduled dates. The guest (Brad) will experience the rate increase as a betrayal of the original agreement because his System 1 anchored on the first number. The emotional damage is not proportional to the dollar amount -- it is proportional to the gap between expectation and reality.

evidence.quote: Now that you have measured the lines, you -- your System 2 -- have a new belief: you know that the lines are equally long. But you still see the bottom line as longer.
evidence.insight: The Muller-Lyer illusion proves that knowing something is fair does not make it feel fair. Even after the guest understands seasonal pricing, their System 1 will still feel the original rate is the 'real' rate. The design cannot eliminate this illusion but can prevent the surprise that transforms a mild discomfort into active distrust.

elements.emotion_rationale: Fairness is the antidote to betrayal. When a guest encounters a price change and feels it was fairly disclosed and transparently calculated, the emotional response shifts from 'they tricked me' to 'the market moved and I was prepared.' Fairness does not require the guest to like the price -- it requires them to feel the process was honest. Fairness at the moment of price disclosure determines whether the guest stays or churns.

do: Show both the original rate and the new rate side by side -- comparison is the foundation of perceived fairness
Use neutral market language: 'rate for the requested date' instead of 'price increase' or 'surcharge'
Explain the why briefly: 'Jan-Feb rates are higher due to seasonal demand' -- one sentence of context
Show the delta explicitly, even when it is $0, to build trust in the system's transparency
dont: Apologize for the price difference ('Sorry, rates have changed') -- apologies imply wrongdoing and amplify the betrayal feeling
Hide the comparison by showing only the new rate -- the absence of context creates suspicion
Frame the price change as the guest's fault ('Because you are rescheduling...') -- the guest should not feel punished for flexibility
Use persuasive language to justify the price ('This is actually a great rate!') -- let the numbers speak for themselves
copy_guidelines.example_good: Your original rate: $280/night. Rate for Oct 22: $301/night. Difference: +$21. (Jan-Feb seasonal rate.)
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Unfortunately, due to seasonal pricing adjustments, your new rate will be $301/night. We apologize for any inconvenience.

animation_feel.feel_description: A calm reveal. When the rate comparison appears, both numbers (original and new) arrive simultaneously with a gentle fade-in, not sequentially. Sequential reveal (old rate... then new rate) creates dramatic tension that amplifies the price shock. Simultaneous reveal presents the comparison as a static fact rather than an unfolding surprise. The sensation is reading a receipt, not watching a price ticker.
animation_feel.duration_range: 150-200ms for the comparison to fully appear

tension_relief.tension_point: The guest discovers the rescheduled date costs more than their original rate. Their System 1 flags this as a potential deception.
tension_relief.relief_point: The comparison display shows both rates side by side with the delta and a one-line seasonal explanation. The guest sees the system is transparent, not manipulative.
tension_relief.timing: The relief must be simultaneous with the tension. The guest should never see the new rate without immediately seeing the original rate and the delta. If there is even a 500ms gap between 'new rate appears' and 'comparison context appears,' the betrayal emotion activates.

personalization_signals: Show the guest's specific original rate, not a generic 'original rates start at...'
Reference the guest's specific dates: 'Your Oct 15 rate was $280. Oct 22 rate is $301.'
If the guest has made previous date changes at $0 delta, reference that: 'Your last swap was cost-neutral. This one has a seasonal adjustment.'
Cumulative disclosure: 'You have paid $X in seasonal adjustments across your lease' -- makes the total visible rather than hidden across individual changes

anti_patterns.pattern: Showing only the new price without a comparison to the original
anti_patterns.reason: Without comparison, the guest must recall the original rate from memory and compute the delta themselves. Under ego depletion, they will get it wrong or not bother -- and the uncertainty will feel like deception even if the difference is small.

coherence_note.similarity: Both address the emotional architecture around financial information. The existing library element (Relief of Guaranteed Income) addresses the host's need to see their money and know it is safe. The new guest-run element (Price Surprise Shield) addresses the guest's need to never encounter an unexpected price change that feels like betrayal.

elements.title: The Weekly Glance: From Vigilance to Ease Over 13 Weeks
elements.problem: The Stays Manager is the most-visited page in the guest journey -- 13+ visits over a single lease. On Week 1, the guest arrives uncertain: they do not yet know whether the platform is reliable, whether their stay information is accurate, or whether anything will go wrong. Their System 2 is fully engaged in parsing a new interface. By Week 7, the guest has developed expectations but also accumulated fatigue from weekly administrative prompts (reviews, photo uploads). By Week 13, the guest is either comfortably habituated or resentfully checked-out. The emotional arc of the Stays Manager determines whether the guest renews, recommends, or abandons. Currently, the flat table design delivers the same emotional experience on Week 1 and Week 13: a wall of data rows that demands System 2 scanning. There is no emotional progression. The page does not reward the guest for returning, does not acknowledge their growing familiarity, and does not adapt its tone to the stage of the relationship. Kahneman's skill acquisition research shows that repeated tasks should feel easier with practice -- but a table that grows each week makes the experience harder, not easier, creating an emotional trajectory of increasing frustration rather than increasing comfort.
elements.solution: Design the Stays Manager's emotional arc across three distinct phases. Week 1-3 (Orientation): the tone is warm, gently instructional, and reassuring. The hero card includes a brief orientation note ('This card updates each week with your current stay'). Copy uses complete sentences. The feeling is 'we are guiding you.' Week 4-9 (Routine): the tone shifts to efficient and confident. Orientation hints disappear. Copy becomes terse and data-forward. The feeling is 'you know how this works; here is what you need.' Week 10-13 (Appreciation): the tone shifts to reflective and grateful. The hero card acknowledges the approaching end ('3 weeks remaining'). The final review prompt is framed warmly. The feeling is 'thank you for being here.' The emotional arc maps to Kahneman's cognitive ease gradient: Week 1 requires System 2 (unfamiliar interface), so the emotional design compensates with warmth. By Week 7, System 1 handles the page (familiar pattern), so the emotional design steps back to efficiency. By Week 13, the relationship deserves acknowledgment, so the design re-engages with human warmth.

evidence.quote: Monday to Friday is a very popular usage pattern... typically looking for really weeknights or weekdays each week... 2-3 month commitments typical.
evidence.insight: The hybrid worker visits weekly for months. Each visit is a micro-interaction competing with work. The emotional design must respect this rhythm: warm when the guest is new and uncertain, invisible when the guest is habituated, and appreciative when the guest has invested months of loyalty.

evidence.quote: As you become skilled in a task, its demand for energy diminishes... A general 'law of least effort' applies to cognitive as well as physical exertion.
evidence.insight: As the guest becomes skilled at reading the Stays Manager, the emotional design must shift from compensating for cognitive effort (warm guidance) to matching cognitive ease (clean efficiency). A design that stays warm and instructional on Week 10 feels patronizing. A design that is terse on Week 1 feels cold.

elements.emotion_rationale: Belonging is the emotional endpoint of a 13-week relationship. Week 1 is about trust. Week 7 is about comfort. Week 13 is about belonging -- the guest should feel that this platform knows them, respects their time, and values their presence. Belonging is what converts a transactional lease into a relationship that drives renewal and referral.

copy_guidelines.voice: warm evolving to efficient to grateful
do: Week 1-3: use complete sentences with context ('Your first stay is this week. Here is what to expect.')
Week 4-9: use terse, data-forward phrases ('Week 7: Oct 14-18. In Progress.')
Week 10-13: add human acknowledgment ('3 weeks remaining. Thank you for being a great guest.')
Use the guest's name at least once on the page across all phases
Reference specific data (dates, property name) rather than generic placeholders
dont: Maintain the same tone from Week 1 through Week 13 -- the relationship evolves and the voice must evolve with it
Use instructional language after Week 3 -- it signals the platform does not trust the guest to know how it works
Use corporate farewell language at lease end ('We hope you enjoyed your experience!') -- it sounds automated
Over-celebrate routine actions ('Amazing! You checked your stay!') -- it feels condescending to a busy professional
copy_guidelines.example_good: Week 7: 'Week 7 of 13. Oct 14-18. All set.' -- Efficient, respectful of the guest's time, acknowledges progress without fanfare.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Week 7: 'Welcome back to your Stays Manager! Here is your weekly update for your stay at the property.' -- Overly formal, wastes words, treats the guest like a first-time visitor.

animation_feel.feel_description: A settling exhale. The hero card loads with a fast start and gentle deceleration, like sitting down in a familiar chair. On Week 1, the card entrance is slightly slower (300ms) to give the guest time to register the new element. By Week 4+, the entrance is faster (200ms) because the guest knows where to look. The sensation across all weeks is arrival without effort -- the information meets the guest where they are, rather than making them search for it.
animation_feel.duration_range: 200-300ms, decreasing over the lease as familiarity grows

tension_relief.tension_point: Does the platform still have my correct stay information? Has anything changed since last week?
tension_relief.relief_point: The hero card loads instantly with the current week's data, confirming everything is accurate and on track. No scanning needed.
tension_relief.timing: Relief must arrive within 2 seconds of page load. The hero card answers both questions (correct data, nothing changed) in a single glance.

personalization_signals: Hero card shows the guest's current week number out of total ('Week 7 of 13'), acknowledging their journey progress
After a completed date change, the hero card briefly notes the change ('Updated: Oct 15 swapped for Oct 22') so the guest sees the platform registered their action
On the first visit after a batched review milestone, the hero card thanks the guest by name if a review was submitted
The lease duration context adapts: early weeks show 'Getting started', mid-lease shows nothing extra, late weeks show 'X weeks remaining'

anti_patterns.pattern: Same emotional tone on every visit regardless of lease week
anti_patterns.reason: A static tone fails to mirror the guest's evolving relationship with the platform. Week 1 uncertainty and Week 13 familiarity are different emotional states that require different tonal responses. Treating them identically signals the platform is not paying attention.
anti_patterns.example_bad: 'Welcome to your Stays Manager' displayed identically on Week 1 and Week 13.

coherence_note.similarity: Both address depletion-aware pacing through the emotional arc of repeated interactions. The existing library element prescribes the host journey should feel like a stroll, with decompression moments after high-effort phases. The new guest-run element prescribes the Stays Manager emotional arc across 13 weeks: warm guidance early, efficient data mid-lease, grateful acknowledgment at close.

elements.title: Proposal Progress Pipeline: Show the Guest Where They Are, What Happens Next, and Who Acts
elements.problem: The guest's proposal journey is a multi-stage pipeline: Submit Proposal, Rental Application, Host Review, Finalize Documents, Lease Documents, Initial Payment. The current design shows this as a horizontal progress tracker with stages marked completed, current, or upcoming. But the pipeline hides the most anxiety-producing information: who must act next and how long it will take. After submitting a proposal, the guest enters a waiting state with no visibility into whether the host has seen the proposal, is reviewing it, or has forgotten about it. Kahneman's research on uncertainty and System 2 activation predicts that unresolved uncertainty forces continuous System 2 monitoring: the guest cannot stop thinking about the pending proposal because they have no information to resolve the ambiguity. This cognitive drain persists for the entire waiting period, competing with the guest's work responsibilities and reducing their engagement with the platform. The Nneka call illustrates the downstream consequence: Brad ends up texting Nneka directly because the platform provides no status visibility.
elements.solution: Transform the progress pipeline from a stage tracker into an action-assignment display. At every stage, the pipeline must answer three questions: (1) 'Where am I?' -- the current stage, highlighted. (2) 'What happens next?' -- a plain-language description of the next step. (3) 'Who needs to act?' -- explicitly: 'Waiting on host' or 'Your action needed' or 'Split Lease processing.' Add estimated timeframes to each waiting state: 'Hosts typically respond within 48 hours.' When the host counters, the pipeline updates to show the guest what changed and what they need to decide, with the counter-offer terms visible directly in the pipeline context, not on a separate page. The pattern is: resolve uncertainty at every moment, even if the resolution is 'nothing has changed yet -- expected response by [date].'

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 311-327
evidence.quote: Progress Tracker (Six Stages): Proposal Submitted (completed), Rental Application Submitted (completed), Review Host Modifications (current/action needed), Finalizing Documents (upcoming), Lease Documents (upcoming), Initial Payment (upcoming).
evidence.insight: The pipeline shows stage names and completion status but not who must act, what the expected duration is, or what happens if nothing happens. 'Review Host Modifications' tells the guest they need to act but does not surface the modifications inline -- the guest must scroll or navigate to find what changed.

evidence.quote: He was texting me and saying, Hey, you know, I can't make it for another day.
evidence.insight: Brad resorts to texting because the platform provides no status channel for his requests. If the proposal pipeline had shown 'Waiting on host -- sent 2 hours ago,' Brad would know his request was in progress. Instead, the opacity drives him off-platform.

evidence.quote: System 2 is activated when an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains.
evidence.insight: The guest's model after submitting a proposal is: 'I acted, now something should happen.' When nothing visibly happens (no status update, no timeframe, no assignment), System 2 activates to manage the uncertainty. This activation persists as low-grade cognitive drain until the uncertainty is resolved. Showing 'Waiting on host -- expected response by Friday' resolves the uncertainty and frees System 2.

evidence.source: kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Busy and Depleted System 2
evidence.quote: Activities that impose high demands on System 2 require self-control, and the exertion of self-control is depleting and unpleasant.
evidence.insight: Monitoring an uncertain outcome is a continuous System 2 demand. Every hour the guest spends wondering 'has the host seen my proposal?' is an hour of depletion that reduces their willingness to engage with the platform for any other purpose. Status resolution is not a convenience feature; it is a depletion prevention mechanism.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: current stage name + who must act next ('Waiting on host' or 'Your action needed'). Secondary: expected timeframe or deadline ('Hosts typically respond within 48 hours. Submitted 14 hours ago.'). Tertiary: the specific content of the current stage (counter-offer terms, document links, payment amount).
elements.disclosure_pattern: Immediate on page load: current stage and action assignment are visible without scrolling. On the same view: estimated time remaining or elapsed time since last action. On interaction (tap current stage): full details of what is required, including counter-offer terms shown inline. Never require navigation to a separate page to see what changed in a counter-offer.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 6 stages in the pipeline (current design is appropriate). Only the current stage shows detailed information; completed stages show a checkmark only, upcoming stages show names only. The action assignment ('Waiting on host') is 3 words maximum. The timeframe estimate is one line maximum.
scan_order: Current stage highlight: which stage is active (System 1: 'Where am I?', under 1 second)
Action assignment label: 'Waiting on host' or 'Your action needed' (System 1: 'Do I need to do anything right now?', 1-2 seconds)
Timeframe: 'Submitted 14 hours ago. Expected response within 48 hours.' (System 2: 'When should I check back?', 2-4 seconds)
Stage content: counter-offer details, document links, payment info (System 2: detailed engagement, 4+ seconds, only if action is needed)
exclude: Pipeline stages that show only names without action assignment. Every stage must indicate who acts.
Waiting states with no estimated timeframe. 'Processing' without a timeline is anxiety, not information.
Counter-offer terms displayed on a separate page from the pipeline. The delta (what changed and by how much) must be visible in the pipeline context.
Completed stages showing full detail. Completed stages need only a checkmark and the completion date -- the cognitive resources should focus on the current stage.

coherence_note.similarity: Both address proposal presentation. The existing library element prescribes pre-packaged proposals for the host (confirm, don't construct). The new guest-run element prescribes the proposal progress pipeline for the guest (show who acts next, expected timeline, and what happens next).

elements.title: Stays Manager Hero Card: Visual Weight That Matches Cognitive Priority
elements.problem: The Stays Manager is the guest's most-visited page -- weekly for 13+ weeks.
